bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, October 6, 1949 [Enclosed in 06501060]

div1.p: Tate identifies himself to Truby and asks if it would be possible for Truby to send him a signed copy of his book about the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Albert E. Truby, October 6, 1949 [Enclosed in 06501060]
div1.opener:
Copy for Dr Hench.
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3 California
October 6, 1949
Brig. General Albert Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I have just heard from a friend back East that you
now reside in California, so being close by in Berkeley, thought I would
write to you.

It is quite unlikely that you will remember me out of
the thousands of Hospital Corpsmen you have been in contact with during
your long service in the Medical Department of the Army, but as I served
under you during your first command, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and
remember you quite well and favorably, I am going to write to you anyway.

I was at Pinar del Rio during the Yellow Fever
(diagnosed Pernicious Malaria) episode there, and later came to Columbia
Barracks and served there from beginning to end of the experiments of
Major Reed's Board. So I served under you and Captain Stark.

I was a clerk at Pinar del Rio and held the same
job at Columbia Barracks Hospital, keeping the S. & W. Reports,
Pay Rolls, etc. I was studying for Asst. Hospl. Steward at the time
and passed with a very high percentage, but was rejected because the
examining board, (Contract Doctors) found I had slight mitral insufficiency.

Captain Stark told me that no Regular Army Board would
have ever considered that sufficient reason for rejection, and if so,
would not have allowed me to take the rest of the examination, which this
Board did.

I am one of the men in the picture in which you appear,
taken on the hospital steps at Columbia Barracks. I was sent to Fort
Bayard, N. M. from Quemados and reenlisted there. There I came down with
a bad case of Bacillary Dysentary, brought in my system from Cuba. Major
Appel, Hospital Commander, said it was the worst case he ever saw that
survived. I was his pet show-off to other doctors for quite awhile.

I took all dictation from doctors at monthly examination
of tubercular patients and made out all the charts. Later was personal
clerk to Major Appel.

I have read all the books written about the Yellow
Fever experiments, and your book, I am happy to say, is the only real,
factual account of that great event. Most of the others were written
by people who were not there.

I was in a position there to learn a great deal about
things, and knew everyone connected with the experiment, and in my
opinion no one has written so truthfully and comprehensively of this
event as yourself.

I read the book at the Public Library here. You
know, I'd give anything to have a copy of that book for myself as
a momento of that great time. Honestly, I hate to write this, but
I wonder, I wonder, if you have a copy of it you could spare?
You can realize what it would mean to me to have a copy signed by
yourself. It would surely be a treasured possesion.

I congratulate you on your achievements in the
Army and your deserved promitions to the highest rank, and it
makes me feel like old times to know that my old C. O. is in the
same great State of California with me.
div1.closer:
With very best wishes,
Cordially & Sincerely yours, /s/ Paul L. Tate /t/Paul L. Tate
formerly Private, H. Corps, U.S. Army
A TRUE COPY:
Wendell B. Patton
WENDELL B. PATTON
Major, MSC
Adjutant
Letterman General Hospital
Presidio of San Francisco, California
